title: Cat. 50  Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Hadrian, A.D. 120/23
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Hadrian  
A.D. 120/23, issued by Hadrian  
Gold; diam. 1.9 cm; 7.34 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Bust of Hadrian right, laureate, cuirass and paludamentum  
Inscribed: IMP CAESAR TRAIAN HADRIANVS AVG  
Reverse: Roma, helmeted, sits left on cuirass, foot on pillow, spear in left hand; in right hand holds Victory carrying a trophy; shield and quiver lean behind  
Inscribed: P M TR P COS III  
RIC II 77; BMCRE III 133; axis: 7:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Katherine K. Adler Memorial, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Alexander, and Ancient Art Purchase funds, 2004.144

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The obverse and reverse inscriptions on this coin are identical to those on cat. 49, Denarius (Coin) Portraying Emperor Hadrian, and offer little help in dating it. The remarkable figure on the reverse, however, gives us some context. The image is not merely the personification of Roma (which had appeared on Roman coins since the early Republic) but is a celebration of the newly official cult of the goddess Roma (Dea Roma), inaugurated by Hadrian. She had actually been a fixture of Hellenistic religion for a long time, and it is not surprising that the philhellene Hadrian was the one to bring the cult to the capital. Besides the issues of coins in her honor, Dea Roma received her own temple in Rome, a double temple in fact, back to back with the other tutelary goddess of Rome, Venus. The temple of Venus and Rome was, when completed, the largest in the city, located between the Roman Forum and the Flavian amphitheater (Hadrian had to move the colossal statue of Nero in order to build his temple). The land on which it was to be built was consecrated on April 21, Rome’s “birthday,” as the Parilia festival was called; the festival was now renamed the Romaia. The consecration of this temple to Rome the Goddess took place in 121, the year Hadrian celebrated the fifth anniversary of his reign; it is likely that this magnificent coin was issued at the same time.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Mols, “Cult of Roma Aeterna.”
